docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show. Art Fairs SOFA NEW YORK 2003: SCULPTURE, OBJECTS AND FUNCTIONAL ART, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street (through Monday). A potpourri of dealers and galleries whose wares run the gamut between art and craft several times over, this fair has an unusually high schlock rate at both ends. But it abounds with jaw-dropping displays of artisanal pyrotechnics in every imaginable medium and usually offers enough high-end material -- both contemporary and historical, Western and nonwestern -- to achieve a worthwhile ratio of entertainment, information and pleasure. Hours: Today, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.; tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Sunday, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $16 (Roberta Smith).

docs.lead_paragraph: The teachers' union yesterday protested what it said was the City Department of Education's attempt to blame a first-year teacher after two high school students threw a stool out a window, striking a pregnant woman. Education officials have said that the teacher would face disciplinary charges for failing to lock the unused sixth-floor classroom from which the stool was thrown on Wednesday.

headline.main: Union Opposes Blaming Teacher For Stool That Struck Woman

docs.abstract: New York City teachers' union is protesting Department of Education's disciplinary action against teacher after two students threw stool out window of classroom of Washington Irving High School; stool hit passerby Rosauro Beristani, who remains hosptalized in good condition; students are charged with assault and suspended (M)
docs.snippet: The teachers' union yesterday protested what it said was the City Department of Education's attempt to blame a first-year teacher after two high school students threw a stool out a window, striking a pregnant woman.    Education officials have said...

docs.lead_paragraph: A pregnant woman was knocked down by a stool hurled out of a sixth-floor window at a Manhattan high school yesterday as she walked down 17th Street near Union Square. Witnesses said the woman, identified by the police as Rosaura Beristani, 29, was carrying a bag of groceries past Washington Irving High School just before 11 a.m. when she was hit in the head by the metal stool and collapsed on the sidewalk.

headline.main: Pregnant Woman Hit by Stool Tossed From School

docs.abstract: Rosaura Beristani, who is seven months pregnant, is seriously injured by stool hurled out of sixth-floor window at Washington Irving High School in Manhattan; fetus is unharmed; two students are charged with assault; neighborhood residents say students are known for throwing things out of school's windows; school officials say that teacher who broke school rule by failing to lock door of empty classroom will be disciplined; photo (L)
docs.snippet: A pregnant woman was knocked down by a stool hurled out of a sixth-floor window at a Manhattan high school yesterday as she walked down 17th Street near Union Square.    Witnesses said the woman, identified by the police as Rosaura Beristani, 29, was...

docs.lead_paragraph: Shannon Minor went to the drugstore last year to buy a home pregnancy test, picked up the local newspaper and read some bad news: her obstetrician, Barbara Pringle, was planning to stop delivering babies. But not only was Dr. Pringle giving up obstetrics, so were four other doctors in Mount Vernon, including Dr. Pringle's husband, Robert, and the Pringles' longtime partner. Within a year only four obstetricians would be practicing in Mount Vernon, a small city in an agricultural valley of the Cascade Mountains, halfway between Seattle and the Canadian border.

headline.main: In Insurance Cost, Woes for Doctors and Women

docs.abstract: Medical malpractice insurance rates for obstetricians are soaring in Washington State and around nation, leading many doctors to stop delivering babies; pregnant women in rural areas, where there are already few obstetricians, must scramble to find doctor; even opponents of federal cap on jury awards against doctors admit shortage is serious; graph of malpractice premiums; photo (M)
